Description.val: This line item funds modifications to the EA-6B aircraft.  The EA-6B Prowler is a four-seat, twin-engine, mid-wing, tactical, electronic attack aircraft.  The EA-6B is employed in both Navy and Marine Corps squadrons to provide DoD tactical electronic attack capability.  Modifications budgeted and programmed include: procurement of Improved Capability III (ICAP III) block upgrades and installation, avionics upgrades and installation, mission planning upgrades and installation, missile control modifications, and readiness initiatives to ensure EA-6B viability in an ever-changing threat environment.

Justification.val: The EA-6B Prowler is a Low Density High Demand electronic jamming platform.  The aircraft are 33+ years old.  Considerable modifications are required in two basic catagories to keep the systems viable:  weapons delivery and airframe reliability.  Weapons delivery includes Airborne Electronic Attack (AEA) systems and its ancillary equipment.  Several systems on the aircraft are based on outdated software and techniques.  Modifications are required to meet and defeat multiple threat signatures as AEA methodologies change.  Modifications are required to keep the aircraft flying safely as it ages.  Fatigue Life Expended (FLE), advanced corrosion, and tired iron must be addressed and repaired.  This OSIP is required to operate and maintain the aircraft and its systems/subsystems until the platform is retired.

Name.@footnote: The increases in Integrated Logistics Support and Other Support across the FYDP are due to the impending aircraft sundown.  As the aircraft approaches sundown, activities will shift from future readiness investments (largely kits and installations)to managing current readiness and sundown activities via Logistics and Other support.

In FY13-18 OSIP 032-85-1 funds recurring costs related to Audio Intercommunication System AIC-45 and Fuel Flow Transmitter installation engineering on the EA-6B aircraft.  Center Wing Section Harvest engineering and modernization kits are an emerging requirement.  The cost to modernize the CWS varies depends on condition.  Across the FYDP (FY14-18), the mix of kits being purchased causes a variation in the yearly unit cost on the Aircraft Systems, Aircraft Avionics, and Aircraft Structures.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Not Installed - PRIOR YR INSTALLATION  COST

Description.val:
This Operational and Safety Improvement Program covers EA-6B Structural, Systems, Sub-Systems, and Avionics modifications and improvement to mission degrading deficiencies discovered during test reviews, flight line inspections, and preventive maintenance inspections related to reliability, maintainability, sustainability, training, and safety of flight. 

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR MILESTONES:
Major milestones include the completion of the Digital Flight Control System test program and Wing Center Section production deliveries.


Current Modifications:
Avionics/Electrical Readiness (Supp) - To address avionic/electrical deficiencies discovered during fleet operations to mitigate safety of flight deficiencies to meet operational requirements.
Air Vehicle Structures Readiness (Supp) - To address structural deficiencies discovered during fleet operations to mitigate safety of flight deficiencies to meet operational requirements.
Sub-Systems Readiness (Supp) - To address sub-system deficiencies discovered during fleet operations to mitigate safety of flight deficiencies to meet operational requirements.
Wing Center Section - Replacement program which replace wings that have either cracked due to stress corrosion or have reached their wing fatigue life limit (reliability)
Aircraft Systems (Systems/Sub-Systems Readiness Improvements) - Includes modifications to improve reliability and maintainability of avionics, electrical, life support, propulsion/power, landing gear, hydraulics, pneumatic, primary secondary flight controls, and environmental control systems. 
Aircraft Avionics ( Avionics Readiness Improvements) - Includes modifications to improve reliability and maintainability of avionics, software, components, wiring, weapons control, communication, navigation, radar, and display systems. 
Aircraft Structures (Structural Readiness Improvements) - Includes required modifications based on fatigue life analysis and aircraft changes to ensure EA-6B aircraft availability, reliability, and maintainability of airframe structural components through FY19.

Funding provided to support all EA-6B airframe readiness, hardware readiness, electrical component readiness, obsolescence prevention, inspections, installations, and safety of flight improvements throughout remaining airframe service.  Fund application to the structure, system/subsystem, and avionics deficiencies will be made to ensure aircraft service readiness and reliability.

Future Modifications: N/A

Archive Modifications:
A Kits
Prior Yr (A Kits) - EA-6B ICAP II Block 89 to 89A Navigation and Communication upgrade.
2ND EGI/ASN-130A Replacement - EA-6B ICAP II Block 89A Navigation upgrade.
Aircraft Wiring Upgrade - Replacement degraded wiring originally installed during Original Equipment Manufacturer production of the EA-6B.
AN/USQ-113 Kits - USQ-113 Communications Jammer Upgrade Phase III
DFCS - The Digital Flight Control System program comprised the adaption of the existing Digital Flight Control Computer and Digital Control Panel to replace the existing Air Navigational Computer (ANC) and control panel that was fitted to the EA-6B aircraft.
Flight Control - Reliability improvements to flight critical equipment.
Hydraulic Systems Upgrade - Upgrades to the hydraulic actuators to include new technology seals to prevent leakage, new barrels and end caps to improve operational reliability and reduce fatigue on components.
Outer Wing Panel - Replacement program with ongoing Fatigue Life Expenditure analysis and airframe changes to ensure EA-6B availability.
Outer Wing Panel (Supp) - To address OWP deficiencies discovered during fleet operations to mitigate safety of flight deficiencies to meet operational requirements.
SDRS Kits - The Structural Data Recording System provided a more accurate recording of the g-force hits on the aircraft.
USQ-113 A Kits (Supp) - The USQ-113 incorporated a Daul Jam Mode capability which doubled the number of targets that could be effectively jammed by the system, and removed unused and hard to obtain circuit card assemblies that improved the availability of the mission-essential equipment.
B Kits
ASN-130A Replacement/2ND EGI - ASN-72 units for installation
DFCS - Digital Flight Controller Weapon Replacement Assembly's, upgrades from F-14 units
Ejection Seat - Upgrade to safety pin sets and seat air flow (cushion)
Hydraulic System Upgrade PR - Replacement of primary and secondary hydraulic pumps (reliability)
Mission Reprogramming - Raymond Recorder set replacement with Digital Storage Memory Unit.
Power PC Integration - Upgrade to the tactical computer (AYK-14), reliability and performance
Prior Yr Equipment (B Kits) - EA-6B ICAP II 89 to 89A Navigation Communications Upgrade
USQ-113 Ext B Kits (Supp) USQ-113 (V)3 to (V)4 parts kits
USQ-113 TOG B Kits (Supp) USQ-113 (V)3 to (V)4 system controller upgrade and RF switch module.

Name.@footnote: The cost growth within this cost element is due to the combination of software/hardware kits being purchased (IRC, MIDs, USB-ENTR, etc.)

Description.val:
This Operational and Safety Improvement Program covers the EA-6B Improved Capabilities III (ICAP III) system modifications to install radar and improve communication receivers, displays, and connectivity.  This modification removed over 70 aging and unreliable Weapons Replaceable Assemblies.  Specifically, the modification program replaced the ALQ-99 Receiver System with the ALQ-218 receiver system, replaced the TDY-43 display system with a new Commercial Off The Shelf based display system for the Pilot and three Electronic Countermeasures Officers (ECMOs), upgraded the Recorder Reproducer Set with a new Digital Recorder, incorporated the Multi-Mission Advanced Tactical Terminal (MATT) to provide reception of data links, incorporated the USQ-113 Communication Receiver/Jammer with the ALQ-218, updated mission planning for ICAP III to Joint Mission Planning System (JMPS), and incorporated Link-16 to include basic electronic warfare battle management capabilities.   The plan to mature all 32 ICAP III to full potential consists of block upgrades with deliveries approximately 24 months apart.  LITENING Pod integration provides a demonstrated capability and usefulness to support integrated targeting and convoy protection when using the AN/AAQ-28 LITENING Pod system on AV/8B aircraft in conjunction with EA-6B aircraft.  

AVIONICS KITS:  Software/hardware modifications for capability improvements and to address obsolescence issues.  Hardware modification kits include Multi-functional Information Distribution System, MATT replacement,  Cryptological mod kits, ARN-153 Tactical Air Navigational System, and associated hardware for future block improvements to correct critical deficiencies in detection  & identification of radar threats in 21st Century Electronic Warfare Environments.

ICAP III BLOCK MODIFICATION/UPGRADES: Efforts associated with the integration of future block upgrades to correct deficiencies and capitalization of advanced technology to improve performance.  Efforts include but are not limited to improvements and corrections to Threat Detection and Jamming Techniques, the integration of the USQ-113 with the ALQ-99, stability corrections to the USQ-113 Commuications Jammer, tactical displays, and the aircraft Operational Flight Plan.

MISSION PLANNING ENVIRONMENT (MPE): MPE requirements include upgrades to the MPE baseline as improvements via ICAP III block upgrades arise. MPE requires framework integration upgrades to avoid Microsoft Operating System obsolescence and out of cycle technology refresh of Mission Planning laptops in a Windows 7 environment. 
 
JAMMER MANAGEMENT REHOST (JMR):
Rehosting of mission software in Higher Order Language provides a significant reduction in cycle time and allows timely response to evolving threats.  JMR reduces maintenance costs for future mission software updates, enables additional jammer control unachievable with current code, and greatly enhances our ability to respond to changing world threats at significantly reduced cost.

HARM BLOCK 5A MISSILE CONTROL: All High Speed Anti-Radiation Missile (HARM) Block 5 missiles in the fleet are being converted to Block 5A. EA-6B aircraft requires software and control panel modifications as well as integration efforts for HARM Block 5A missile control. 

Additional outyear funds are provided to ensure aircraft mission systems readiness and reliability to counter increasingly sophisticated and agile threats to Fleet and Operating Forces throughout the remaining airframe service.  These must be applied to all ICAP II and ICAP III systems, to include; the avionics, mission system hardware, mission system software, mission planning environment, and all other aircraft mission sub-systems.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: Following a Full and Open Competition, Milestone II approval was received, and an Engineering and Manufacturing Development (EMD) Research Development Test & Evaluation development contract was awarded to the Northrop Grumman Corporation in March 1998.  Following a Development Test/Operational Test test period, completion of an Operational Assessment and an LRIP decision, an Low Rate Initial Production contract was awarded in FY03. Following completion of Operational Evaluation and a Milestone III decision, a full rate production contract was awarded in the 2nd quarter FY06.  Additional Full Rate Production contracts designated for Lot 3 & Lot 4 were awarded in FY08.
